@14:56: "the rocket goes up with the same change in momentum". Let's say the rocket is massive and the gas being ejected are not of sufficient velocity to apply a force necessary to overcome the force of gravity. So all you've done is to reduce the contact force of the rocket with the ground, but the rocket would not launch and hence it's vertical velocity would still be zero and its momentum would still be zero. The issue as I see it is that you don't have a closed and isolated system and thus the conservation of momentum would not apply. But perhaps you can explain to me why I'm wrong.

I have a question: Thinking about a vehicle accelerating from 0 to 60 and then slowing from 60 to 0. Is the energy to accelerate the vehicle from 0 to 60 the same as the energy to slow the vehicle from 60 to 0? ... I contend that more energy is required to accelerate to 60 than is required to slow the vehicle to 0. The reason for my conclusion is that wheel and bearing friction must be overcome to accelerate the vehicle, while the same friction assists with slowing the vehicle. Therefore the energy required to slow down the vehicle is less than the energy necessary to accelerate the vehicle. ... What do you think?

One of the ways I think about the uncertainty principle is to think of it like a line graph .
You can tell the slope of a line function on a graph when it is drawn out by just calculating its rise over its run, however, if you only had a single point from that graph you could not be certain what the slope of the line resulting from that function would be. And likewise if you have a line drawn out it has infinite potential locations for you to be along that line.

3:00 "The quantity of motion" ??? Actually, momentum is dealing with mass, and the relative difference in the direction of travel that is taking place within space-time. If you start by looking at motion in its simplest form, the rest are mere details. For starters, every object that exists within the 4D environment known as space-time, is in motion, and the magnitude of that motion is exactly the same as the magnitude of motion that photons of light have as they move across space. In turn, all that can be changed, is the direction of travel that takes place within the 4D space-time environment. Let's call that magnitude of motion, "c". So your car, for instance, is currently in motion with the magnitude being the "c" magnitude of motion. Unlike light however, a percentage of that motion is across the dimension of time, and the remainder is across space. If your car was truly at rest in space in the space-time environment, its entire motion would be across the dimension of time. Anyhow, if you make a simple geometric representation of this ongoing "c" motion of an object, you will immediately see the cause of the Special Relativity(SR) phenomena, and you can also use it to derive the SR mathematical equations, including deriving the Lorentz transformation equations, and you can complete this simple task in mere minutes.

Another quiz question: if the golf cart had a speed of only 4m/s, its momentum would be smaller than that of the truck with the elephant going at 1m/s. But in fact the golf cart with this lower momentum could STILL do more damage if it hit a target that can't get out of the way easily. The reason is that momentum doesn't actually determine the amount of damage. It's the transfer of ENERGY that matters, because it's what goes into the stretching of molecular bonds!

F_ext = Δ P_system / Δt. A system's momentum, in a given direction, is conserved IF THERE IS AN ABSENCE OF A NET EXTERNAL FORCE IN THAT DIRECTION. Why do so many sources (including Wikipedia) keep referring to the process of momentum transfer ---- in the presence of a net external force ---- as "momentum conservation"? That's wrong.

This is similar to problems in mechanics where one writes: ΔPE + ΔKE = Work done by dissipative forces --- if dissipative forces can be considered negligible then Mechanical Energy is practically conserved, otherwise the equation describes the transfer of KE to PE (and vice-versa) in the presence of dissipative forces.

The train may actually speed up a bit. If the train is following the curve of the earth's surface, the bottom of the train is going a bit slower. The sand, on the other hand, is falling toward the earth's center at a higher speed than the bottom of the train, thus the sand would tend to push the train forward a tiny, tiny bit.

Regarding the Heisenberg principle:

Professor Heisenberg was speeding along the road, well above the speed limit, when he was stopped by the police.
With more than just a slight hint of sarcasm in his voice, the policeman asks the good professor "Do you know how fast you were going, eh?"
PH: "No, but I know exactly where I am."
Policeman, looking down at his lidar gun: "You were doing, exactly, 123.456 miles per hour!"
PH: "Oh great! Now I'm lost!"

the difference in momentum isn't what makes the golf cart hurt less.  imagine that the electric truck is infinitely massive (!) and then find the best case for the golf cart and the worst case for the truck. the best case would be a perfectly inelastic collision. you probably weigh about 50 kg, and you're at rest, so with momentum conserved you and the cart will be moving at 5200 kg m/s / (260 kg + 50 kg) = 17 m/s. it lost [(20 m/s)^2 - (17 m/s)^2)] * 260 kg = 30 thousand joules of energy that you and the golf cart jointly ate. it's harder than you are, so it dents and you get squished. if the infinitely massive (momentous?) truck hits you at 1 m/s and you bounce off of it (likely) you'll be going 2 m/s afterwards, so you'll have gained (2 m/s)^2 * 50 kg = 200 joules of kinetic energy, which leaves you shaken, but not stirred.

My guess:

Well, the train need a high torque force to move the mass. So, when it reaches full speed, the mass is "pushing" the train forward, due to momentum. Once the sand is lost over time, the mass decreases, reducing the momentum. Because the train has high torque, it doesn't have high speed, so the final velocity is due to the mass momentum.

The train losing mass over time results in lost of velocity.

ok, I have no clue lol

For a more realistic train, the engine is constantly doing work against resistance forces to keep the train going. The question is what happens to those forces when the train loses mass - air resistance is purely based on velocity, so that force stays the same, but friction with the track is limited by the normal force between the train and the track, which depends on the mass. However, so long as the wheels don't skid, that force also remains the same, so the net force on the train stays the same - if it wasn't accelerating before, that net force was zero, so, while the sand leaking reduces its mass, zero net force means zero acceleration. The empty train would accelerate faster, but the top speed wouldn't change.
